title: A brief comparison of test equating methods
code: mod1 <- mirt(d3a[,1:10], 1, 'Rasch', verbose = FALSE)  mod2 <- mirt(d3a[,11:20], 1, 'Rasch', verbose = FALSE)   coef_ls1 <- list(a = rep(1,10),                   b = coef(mod1, simplify=TRUE, IRTpars = TRUE)$item[,'b'],                  c = rep(0,10)) coef_ls2 <- list(a = rep(1,10),                   b = coef(mod2, simplify=TRUE, IRTpars = TRUE)$item[,'b'],                  c = rep(0,10))  req1 <- irt.eq(n_items = 10, coef_ls1, coef_ls2, method="TS", A=1, B=0) # true score rx <- freqtab(rowSums(d3a[,1:10]), scales = 0:10)  ry <- freqtab(rowSums(d3a[,11:20]), scales = 0:10)  req2 <- equate(rx, ry, type = "i") # identity  req3 <- equate(rx, ry, type = "l") # linear  req4 <- equate(rx, ry, type = "e", smooth = "loglin", degrees = 3) # equipercentile with loglinear smoothing  # Leunbach model lfit <- leunbach_ipf(d3a_sum) ## Warning in leunbach_ipf(d3a_sum): Removed 2 rows with missing values #leunbach_equate(lfit) lboot <- leunbach_bootstrap(lfit, n_cores = 4, nsim = 100) leq <- get_equating_table(lboot)  # summary table max_score <- 10  eq_table <- data.frame(identity = pmin(pmax(req2$conc$yx, 0), max_score),                         linear = pmin(pmax(req3$conc$yx, 0), max_score),                         equiperc_loglin3 = pmin(pmax(req4$conc$yx, 0), max_score),                        leunbach_rounded = leq$rounded,                        IRT_truescore = req1$tau_y,                         leunbach_expected = leq$expected,                        IRT_thetaequivalent = req1$theta_equivalent,                        leunbach_theta = leq$log_theta                        ) %>%    round(2)  kable(eq_table) eq_table %>%    select(!c(leunbach_theta,IRT_thetaequivalent)) %>%    pivot_longer(!identity) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = identity, y = value, color = name, shape = name, linetype = name)) +   geom_point(size = 2) +    geom_line() +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0:10), minor_breaks = NULL) +   scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(0:10)) +   scale_color_viridis_d() +   theme_bw() +   labs(title = "Test equating on sum score scale",        color = "Equating model", shape = "Equating model", linetype = "Equating model",        y = "Predicted Y value", x = "X value") eq_table %>%    select(c(identity,leunbach_theta,IRT_thetaequivalent)) %>%    pivot_longer(!identity) %>%    filter(identity %in% c(1:9)) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = identity, y = value, color = name, shape = name)) +   geom_point(size = 3) +    geom_line() +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0:10), minor_breaks = NULL) +   scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(-2:2)) +   scale_color_viridis_d() +   theme_bw() +   labs(title = "Test equating on theta scale",        color = "Equating model", shape = "Equating model",        y = "Predicted Y value", x = "X value", caption = "Note: Min and max scores are excluded, since these need to be imputed for both methods.") +   theme(plot.caption = element_text(face = "italic", hjust = 0))

code: d3a <- read.delim("data/data3a.csv", sep = ";") head(d3a) ##   a_sum c_sum ## 1     1     8 ## 2     4     4 ## 3     4     7 ## 4     6     3 ## 5     8     5 ## 6     6     6 fit <- leunbach_ipf(d3a, verbose = FALSE) ## Warning in leunbach_ipf(d3a, verbose = FALSE): Removed 2 rows with missing ## values summary(fit) ## Leunbach Score Parameter Estimation - Summary ## ============================================== ## Power Series Distribution with Generalized Symmetric Functions ##  ## N = 498 observations ## Test 1: scores 0 to 10 (observed:  0 to 10) ## Test 2: scores 0 to 9 (observed: 1 to 9) ## Total:  scores 0 to 19 (observed:  1 to 19) ##  ## === Goodness of Fit === ##  ## 1. Likelihood Ratio Test (observed vs expected counts): ##    Likelihood ratio G² =    53.75 (df = 63, p = 0.7904) ##    Pearson chi-square  =    49.08 ##  ## 2. Goodman-Kruskal Gamma Test (one-sided): ##    Tests if observed correlation exceeds expected under the model. ##    Gamma (observed)    =   0.0005 ##    Gamma (expected)    =  -0.0032 ##    Standard error      = 3671.3724 ##    Z statistic         =    -0.00 (p = 0.5000, one-sided) ##  ## 3. Orbit Analysis (person fit): ##    Run analyze_orbits() separately to assess the number of cases ##    outside 95% confidence regions of orbit distributions. ##  ## Converged: TRUE (after 23 iterations) print(fit) ## Leunbach Score Parameter Estimation ## ==================================== ## Power Series Distribution with Generalized Symmetric Functions ##  ## N = 498 observations ##  ## Test 1 score parameters (gamma): ##      9        20  4.179715  1.430243 ##     10         3  0.651356 -0.428699 ##  ## Test 2 score parameters (delta): ##  ##  Score Frequency    Delta Log_Delta ##      0         0 0.000000        NA ##      1        12 1.000000  0.000000 ##      2        32 2.453814  0.897644 ##      3        57 4.122441  1.416445 ##      4        88 6.247856  1.832238 ##      5        84 6.072293  1.803736 ##      6        89 6.343274  1.847395 ##      7        73 5.337807  1.674815 ##      8        43 3.203051  1.164104 ##      9        20 1.535259  0.428699 ##  ## Total score parameters (sigma = Test1 + Test2): ##  ##  Score Frequency      Sigma Log_Sigma ##      0         0   0.000000        NA ##      1         0   1.000000  0.000000 ##      2         0   5.761172  1.751141 ##      3         2  19.056078  2.947386 ##      4         4  50.871418  3.929301 ##      5        14 106.112295  4.664498 ##      6        25 185.860485  5.224996 ##      7        39 285.824799  5.655379 ##      8        54 378.957812  5.937425 ##      9        70 453.576111  6.117163 ##     15        13 131.201551  4.876735 ##     16        11  67.296568  4.209109 ##     17         5  29.803253  3.394618 ##     18         1   8.503273  2.140451 ##     19         0   1.000000  0.000000 ## Likelihood Ratio Test: ##    LR = 53.75  DF = 63  p = 0.7904 ##  ## 2. Goodman-Kruskal Gamma Test (one-sided): ##    Gamma (observed) = 0.0005 ##    Gamma (expected) = -0.0032 ##    SE = 3671.3724 ##    Z = -0.00  p = 0.5000 ##  ## 3. code: d1 <- read.delim("data/data1.csv", sep = ";") head(d1) ##   a_sum b_sum c_sum ## 1     2     4    NA ## 2     2     5    NA ## 3     5     7    NA ## 4     4     5    NA ## 5     5     5    NA ## 6     7     7    NA fit_ab <- leunbach_ipf(d1[,c(1,2)]) ## Warning in leunbach_ipf(d1[, c(1, 2)]): Removed 500 rows with missing values fit_bc <- leunbach_ipf(d1[,c(2,3)]) ## Warning in leunbach_ipf(d1[, c(2, 3)]): Removed 500 rows with missing values indirect1 <- leunbach_indirect_equate(fit_ab, fit_bc,                                      direction_ab = "1to2",                                      direction_bc = "1to2") print(indirect1) ## Leunbach Indirect Equating ## ========================== ##  ## Path: Test1 -> Test2 -> Test2 ## Method: optimize ##  ## Source (Test1) range:  0 to 10 ## Anchor (Test2) range: 0 to 10 ## Target (Test2) range: 0 to 10 ##  ##  Test1    Theta Expected_Test2 Rounded_Test2 ##      0  -5.0000           0.00             0 ##      1  -2.0865           1.23             1 ##      2  -1.4308           2.20             2 ##      3  -0.9309           3.22             3 ##      4  -0.4880           4.19             4 ##      5  -0.0846           5.08             5 ##      6   0.3154           5.98             6 ##      7   0.7833           7.09             7 ##      8   1.4251           8.44             8 ##      9   2.3503           9.42             9 ##     10   5.0000          10.00            10

text: Performs orbit analysis Leunbach model.  total score (orbit), computes expected distribution (Test1, Test2) score pairs cumulative probabilities assessing person fit.

title: Analyze Orbits for Leunbach Model — analyze_orbits

text: fit leunbach_ipf object leunbach_ipf() alpha Significance level critical values (default 0.05) verbose Print detailed output

title: Analyze Orbits for Leunbach Model — analyze_orbits
text: list class "leunbach_orbits" containing: orbits: Matrix expected percentages within total score left_right:  Cumulative probabilities P(X ≤ x | S = s) right_left: Cumulative probabilities P(X ≥ x | S = s) crit_left: Critical values left tail total score crit_right: Critical values right tail total score crit_values: Combined critical values (two-tailed) expected_critical: Expected number persons significant differences variance_expected: Variance expected critical count n_significant: Number observed persons significant differences orbit_df:  Degrees freedom orbit

title: Analyze Orbits for Leunbach Model — analyze_orbits
text: total score S = X + Y, orbit consists valid (X, Y) pairs. expected probability cell within orbit : P(X = x | S = s) = (gamma_x * delta_y) / sigma_s Cumulative probabilities computed directions: Left--right: P(X ≤ x | S = s) - tests Test1 score unusually low Right--left: P(X ≥ x | S = s) - tests Test1 score unusually high

text: Indirect equating works chaining two direct equatings: score x Test , find expected score Test B (typically non-integer) Find expected Test C scores integer B scores Interpolate get expected Test C score non-integer B score Round get equated integer score

title: Indirect Equating via an Anchor Test — leunbach_indirect_equate
code: # Fit models for A-B and B-C fit_ab <- leunbach_ipf(data_ab) #> Error: object 'data_ab' not found fit_bc <- leunbach_ipf(data_bc) #> Error: object 'data_bc' not found  # Indirect equating:  Test1 of fit_ab → Test2 of fit_ab → Test2 of fit_bc indirect <- leunbach_indirect_equate(fit_ab, fit_bc,                                        direction_ab = "1to2",                                        direction_bc = "1to2") #> Error: object 'fit_ab' not found print(indirect) #> Error: object 'indirect' not found

title: Estimate Leunbach Score Parameters using Iterative Proportional Fitting — leunbach_ipf
code: leunbach_ipf(   data,   max_score1 = NULL,   max_score2 = NULL,   max_iter = 1000,   tol = 1e-10,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Estimate Leunbach Score Parameters using Iterative Proportional Fitting — leunbach_ipf
text: data data. frame matrix two columns: Column 1: Sum scores Test 1 Column 2: Sum scores Test 2 max_score1 Maximum possible score Test 1 (default: max observed) max_score2 Maximum possible score Test 2 (default: max observed) max_iter Maximum number iterations IPF tol Convergence tolerance verbose Print iteration progress

title: Estimate Leunbach Score Parameters using Iterative Proportional Fitting — leunbach_ipf
text: list class "leunbach_ipf" containing: gamma: Score parameters Test1 (generalized symmetric functions) delta: Score parameters Test2 (generalized symmetric functions) sigma: Score parameters total score (Test1 + Test2) log_gamma: Log gamma parameters log_delta: Log delta parameters log_sigma: Log sigma parameters fitted: Fitted frequency table observed:  Observed frequency table iterations: Number iterations convergence converged:  Logical indicating convergence test1_scores: Score values Test1 test2_scores: Score values Test2 total_scores: Score values total score g_sq: Likelihood ratio test statistic chi_sq: Pearson chi-square statistic df:  Degrees freedom p_value: P-value likelihood ratio test

title: Estimate Leunbach Score Parameters using Iterative Proportional Fitting — leunbach_ipf
text: model based power series distribution (PSD) sum scores Rasch models.  test k polytomous items, probability obtaining sum score r : $$P(R = r | \theta) = \frac{\gamma_r \theta^r}{\sum_s \gamma_s \theta^s}$$ \(\gamma_r\) generalized symmetric function order r item parameters, \(\theta = exp(\beta)\) person parameter. model -parameterized, apply identification constraints: \(\gamma_{min}\) = 1 (lowest observed score parameter fixed 1) \(\delta_{min}\) = 1 (lowest observed score parameter fixed 1) highest score parameters constrained product equals product score parameters (Rasch-style constraint) sigma parameters total score (S = X + Y) computed : $$\sigma_s = \sum_{x+y=s} \gamma_x \delta_y$$

title: Estimate Leunbach Score Parameters using Iterative Proportional Fitting — leunbach_ipf
text: Leunbach, G. (1976). probabilistic measurement model assessing whether two tests measure personal factor. Copenhagen: Danish Institute Educational Research. Adroher, N. D., Kreiner, S., Young, C., Mills, R., & Tennant, . (2019). Test equating sleep scales: Applying Leunbach’s model. BMC Medical Research Methodology, 19(1), 141. https://doi.org/10.1186/s12874-019-0768-y Kreiner, S. (2007). Validity objectivity:  Reflections role nature Rasch models. Nordic Psychology, 59(3), 268-298. https://doi.org/10.1027/1901-2276.59.3.268

code: # Simulate test score data set.seed(123) n <- 500 theta <- rnorm(n) test1 <- pmin(pmax(round(3 + 1.5 * theta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.8)), 0), 6) test2 <- pmin(pmax(round(2.5 + 1.3 * theta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.7)), 0), 5) score_data <- data.frame(test1 = test1, test2 = test2)  # Estimate parameters (specifying max possible scores) fit <- leunbach_ipf(score_data, max_score1 = 6, max_score2 = 5,
